speaker: Queena
sentence: Just because there were so many events, banners we have to make, and the fact that we had to make them in rapid successions, and, like, it's one after… So, Canva was so nice for us to make sure that, um, the kind of theme was on point, because we could just, like, you know, copy and paste it over into another template, and then maintain the font, maintain the color scheme, And we can transition from the PowerPoint to making a banner.

speaker: Queena
sentence: So that's, like, the really nice option of that, and… Um, afterwards, I haven't been using it as much because I've been also… For us to, like, use Figma, for example, or to use other softwares, so it's, like, slightly declining.

sentence: I feel like it's more like Adobe Illustrators and stuff, because, um, like, I also applied to, like, a bunch of, like, clubs, like, for media, like, roles, and they told me that they don't accept Canva.

speaker: Yoyo
sentence: And I feel like, since I stepped into uni, Um, I use it for, like, my… I think the first social media post I'm doing for, um, a club called Designer Columbia, like, the only club… the design club at Columbia, And then I stopped, and I switched, like, Figma, because, like, I thought it was, like, super hard that I can make it, like, really original.

sentence: And also, um, because, like, Illustrator, it's connected to, like, Adobe, and then functions of, like, Photoshop, so you could easily, like, edit images.

sentence: I mean, Figma has, like, related things, but it's, like… It's, like, part of, like, a plugin, and you have to, like, you have to, like, find it yourself from, like, an icon, like, library and things like that, and their icons are, like, not as diverse.

speaker: Yoyo
sentence: It's Canvas, so probably, if I need to use, like, Figma, I probably have to, like, draw everything.

speaker: Frank

speaker: Yoyo
sentence: Um, I feel like, um… that kind of happened in, like, grade 7 or 8, because, like, Because I'd say design, like, throughout my high school years, and then, um, we started to, like, use different softwares, like Adobe Illustrator, And then I think I used Illustrator for, like, my flat pack project, where we had to, like, Well, I guess we had to, like, print parts, and then, like, just, like, assemble them together after, like, laser cutting and stuff, and I felt… I felt like, oh, okay, oh, there'll be illustrator's, like, extremely more useful than Canva, especially where you're looking at, like, dimensions, too.

speaker: Yoyo
sentence: And then you're just making, like, organic shapes instead of, like…like, abstract, like, squares and, like, circles and things like that, so I felt that was really useful, so I kind of just started, like, switching to Adobe Illustrator afterwards.

speaker: Frank
sentence: Once you discovered illustrator, why would you continue using it, or why did you decide that it was a good time investment to invest into Figma and Adobe Illustrator instead of just sticking to Canva the whole time?

speaker: Yoyo
sentence: Um, I think especially with Figma, because I was more on the UI side, And then the Figma, kind of like… I feel like it's just easier to navigate, because you could put, like, all the pages on the same kind of, like, document, and then you could, like, just scroll through, like, very, like, like, however you want, because for… I think for Figma, if you want to create, like, new pages, it's basically, like, right afterwards, you have to, like, switch back, like, a lot of times.

speaker: Yoyo
sentence: And I feel like for, like, Um, I guess for, like, I feel like for Adobe Illustrator and Figma, they have, like, really good, like, dimension settings and stuff, so I could, like… I could, like, put my, like, pieces, like, exactly… Um, like, on where I want them to be.

speaker: Yoyo
sentence: And for Figma, it's like, they don't have, like… I think they do have grids, But their goods are, like, not that useful, because it's, like, not, like, specific enough, I guess.

speaker: Yoyo
sentence: So if you're like, that's when I really switched to, like, Illustrator and Figma, because I need to be, like, more, like, I guess, like, accurate, um, with dimensions and things, if I wanna, like, work in that kind of field.

speaker: Frank
sentence: Got it, so what I'm hearing is that… You switched from Canva to Adobe Illustrator and Figma, because Canva grading and dimensions are not very precise.

speaker: Yoyo
sentence: Which is why I'm, like, still more focused on, like, I guess illustrators and things, and I do know that Figma, they also do have, like, AI editors and stuff, but I feel like they come as a plugin.

speaker: Yoyo
sentence: So, like, if I wanna, like, really use Canva for, like, design purposes, I probably need to, like, switch, like, Photoshop, or other things like Snapseed to, like, edit, like, photos, and then put… and then paste them in.

speaker: Yoyo
sentence: Which was, like, you really don't want to, like, use two different, like, softwares when you can basically use one, which is the case with, like, Illustrator.

speaker: Yoyo
sentence: Okay, like, definitely Adobe, like, the whole set of Adobe, because they're, like, super professional with what they do.

speaker: Yoyo
sentence: And then I feel like Figma, it's really debatable, because I know some companies do not like it, because they feel like it's also a bit, like, Canva-ish, but of course, it's like, It's, like, more like… it's definitely, like, more professional, and you do have, like, more flexibility with it, and you… basically, UI designer, they start with Figma when you do, like, basic, like, wireframing.

speaker: Yoyo
sentence: But if you want to actually, like, go into them, Um, you basically… I feel like you need to use, like, more, like, other softwares, but I feel like it really differs for, like, depending on the company, but I feel like Figma, it's like, for starters, and probably internships, I feel like that's enough.

speaker: Yoyo
sentence: And then I feel like it blends into, like, Adobe quite well, so I feel like it's basically those two.

sentence: Um, and I guess another reason why I might still use Canva in the future is, for example, like, if there's so many, like, events that's gonna happen, like, each week, and I really don't have the time to, like, really navigate to, like, Illustrator or, like, Figma a lot, then I'll probably just, like, put it in Canva for, like, low-stakes stuff.

speaker: Yoyo
sentence: And I feel like it really depends on the purpose, because I feel like, um… If Canva switched to something more like Illustrator, people will not… I feel like people… it doesn't make people want to use Canva more, because Illustrator's already there, and it's, like, something that's always been there.

speaker: Yoyo
sentence: So I feel like that's… that's something that makes Canva, like, really special, and I feel like if they really change it, something more Figma-like, or something more Illustrator-like.
